Alwhyle ye drynke, 'midst age and ache ybent,</br>Ah creep not comfortlesse besyde our streame;</br>(Sweete nurse of hope) afflyction's downwarde sente,</br>Wythe styll smalle voyce, to rouze from thryftlesse dreame;</br>Each wyng to prune, that shiftythe everie spraie.</br>In wytelesse flyghte, and chyrpythe lyfe awaie.

Alwhyle ye lave — suche solace may be founde</br>"When kynde the hande, why 'neath its healynge faynte?"</br>"Payne shall recure, the heartes corruptede wounde,"</br>"Farre gone is that, whych feelethe not its playnte."</br>"Ay kyndrede angel smote, Betheseda gave"</br>"Newe vyrtues forthe, — and felt her troublede wave."

Thus drynke, thus lave — nor evermore lamente;</br>Oure sprynges but flowe pale anguish to befriende;</br>Howe fayre the meed that followe the contente!</br>How bleste to live, and fynde suche anguish mende!</br>How bleste to dye, when sufferynge faithe makes sure,</br>At lyfe's high founte, an everlastynge cure!</br>
